title: COMMUNITY BOARDS; The Brooklyn Meetings, From Sea Gate to Dumbo

body: THE SETTING Coney Island on Palm Sunday, half an hour before what would ordinarily be the first run of the Cyclone for the year. A gloomy drizzle ensured that only a few die-hard Coney fans and wooden roller-coaster enthusiasts would be on hand for what to them is a sign of the turn of the season, a herald of warm weather and days on the boardwalk.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND -- BUZZ; Cyclone Riders Await the First Screams of Spring

body: Between the Manhattan Bridge and the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, nestled under the shadow of the mammoth Watchtower Society headquarters, sits one of the most elaborately decorated industrial buildings in Brooklyn. The factory, at Bridge and York Streets in the tiny neighborhood of Vinegar Hill, was built in 1909 for the Thomson Meter Company,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: VINEGAR HILL; Treasure or Eyesore, Old Building Evokes Passion

title: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Communities Speak Up: Where the Boards Meet in March

body: In recent weeks, the jump in fuel oil and gasoline prices has emerged as a potent political issue. Homeowners who rely on oil heat have had to deal with surprisingly high bills this winter, but the impact is more widespread, rippling throughout the economy in many ways. And, as with all economic dislocations, some have actually benefited from the
title: High Cost of Oil Seeps Its Way Into Everyday Lives, and Pocketbooks

body: Where a developer recently envisioned an upscale marina and an ultramodern hotel, park planners now want to build a marsh. About 150 years after the natural shoreline disappeared, replaced by bulkheads and piers, state officials and the Brooklyn Bridge Park Development Corporation hope to return estuary grasses to a cove near the Manhattan Bridge.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO; New Hotel? No Thanks, They'd Prefer a Marsh
